Word-based Machine Translation

XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX

MT is one of the most widely used NLP application. It is an example of end-to-end NLP, and MT-like architectures can be found in many other applications.

We focus on word-based MT which is not the state-of-the-art anymore, but a foundation and blueprint for modern mechanisms.

MT as Structured Prediction

Define a parametrised model sθ(t,s)sθ(t,s) measuring how well a target sentence tt matches a source sentence ss, learn the parameters θθ from training data, and find

argmaxtsθ(t,s)(1)(1)argmaxt⁡sθ(t,s)

XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX

Noisy Channel Model for MT

A generative process (the speaker's brain):

  • generate target sentence tt according to p(t)p(t).
  • Transmit tt through a noisy channel p(s|t)p(s|t) to generate source ss.

For a graphical view on the noisy channel see my slides.

The distribution over target words and the channel noise model define a joint distribution p(s,t)=p(t)p(s|t)p(s,t)=p(t)p(s|t). To use it for translation we operate it backwards:

t∗=argmaxtp(t|s)=argmaxtp(t)p(s|t).(2)(2)t∗=argmaxt⁡p(t|s)=argmaxt⁡p(t)p(s|t).

For the structured prediction recipe this means setting

sθ(t,s)=p(t)p(s|t).sθ(t,s)=p(t)p(s|t).

In Machine Translation:

  • p(t)p(t) is usually referred to as language model.
  • p(s|t)p(s|t) is referred to as translation model.

Here we focus on translation models.

A Naive Baseline Translation Model

The most straightforward translation model translates words one-by-one, in the order of appearance:

pNaiveθ(s|t)=∏ilength(s)θsi,tipθNaive(s|t)=∏ilength⁡(s)θsi,ti
where θs,tθs,t is the probability of translating tt as ss. θθ is often referred to as translation table.

Using parallel data of paired source and target sentences, we can train the model using the Maximum Likelihood Estimator:

θs,t=#train(s,t)#train(t)θs,t=#Dtrain(s,t)#Dtrain(t)

Here #train(s,t)#Dtrain(s,t) is the number of times we see target word tt translated as source word ss, and #train(t)#Dtrain(t) the number of times we the target word tt in total.

import scala.collection.mutable.HashMap
case class Param(src:String, tgt: String, prob: Double)
type NaiveModel = Seq[Param]
def learn(data:Seq[(Sentence,Sentence)]):NaiveModel = {
  //data structures to store counts in nominator and denominator
  val norm = new HashMap[String,Double] withDefaultValue 0.0
  val counts = new HashMap[(String,String),Double] withDefaultValue 0.0
  //do the counting
  for ((target,source) <- data) {
    for (i <- 0 until target.tokens.length) {
      norm(target.tokens(i).word) += 1.0
      counts(source.tokens(i).word -> target.tokens(i).word) += 1.0
    }    
  }
  //convert the map to a sequence of parameters
  counts.toSeq map {case ((source,target),count) => Param(source,target,count/norm(target
)) }
}

Decoding with the Naive Model

Translation is often called decoding and means:

argmaxtp(t)p(s|t)argmaxt⁡p(t)p(s|t)
How can we achieve this for the Naive Model?

import uk.ac.ucl.cs.mr.statnlpbook.chapter.languagemodels._
def decode(source:Sentence, model:NaiveModel, lm:LanguageModel) = {
  //create a mapping from source words to relevant parameters
  val source2targets = model groupBy (_.src) 
  def translate(token:Token) = {
    val candidates:Seq[Param] = source2targets(token.word)
    val scoredByLM = candidates map (p => p.copy(prob = p.prob * lm.probability(p.tgt)))
    scoredByLM.maxBy(_.prob).tgt
  }
  //translate word-by-word (for which LM does this work?)
  val words = source.tokens map translate
  Document(IndexedSeq(words))
}
val source = train(1)._2 //"klein ist das Haus"
val lm = UniformLM(model.map(_.tgt).toSet)
val target = decode(source, model, lm) 
target.toText

The naive model is broken in several ways. Most severely, it ignores the fact that word order can differ and still yield (roughly) the same meaning.

IBM Model 2

IBM Model 2 is one of the most influential translation models, even though these days it is only indirectly used in actual MT systems, for example to initialize translation and alignment models.

Alignment

The core difference of Model 2 is the introduction of latent auxiliary variables aa:

  • ai∈[0…length(t)]ai∈[0…length⁡(t)] for each source token i∈[1…length(s)]i∈[1…length⁡(s)]
  • ai=jai=j means source token ii is aligned with the target token jj.
  • aiai can be 00 to point to a NULL token to omit source words.

Below you see a simple example of an alignment.

1
2
3
val target = segment("NULL the house is small").sentences(0)
val source = segment("klein ist das Haus").sentences(0)
Renderer.renderAlignment(target,source,Seq(1->2,2->3,3->1,4->0))

val target2 = segment("NULL 家 わ 小さいい です").sentences(0)
val source2 = segment("The house is small").sentences(0)
Renderer.renderAlignment(target2,source2,Seq(0 -> 0, 1 -> 1, 3 -> 3, 4 -> 2))
XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX
XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX

Model 2 defines a distribution p(s,a|t)p(s,a|t). A translation model can be derived by marginalizing out the alignments

p(s|t)=∑ap(s,a|t).p(s|t)=∑ap(s,a|t).

Model Parametrization

IBM Model 2 has two sets of parameters θ=(α,β)θ=(α,β)

  • α(s|t)α(s|t): probability of translation target word tt into source word ss.
  • β(j|i,lt,ls)β(j|i,lt,ls): probability of aligning the source token ii with target token jj, conditioned on the target length ltlt and source length lsls.

Model 2 defines a conditional distribution over source sentences and alignments, conditioned on a target sentence and a desired source sentence length

pIBM2θ(s1…sls,a1…als|t1…tlt,ls)=∏ilsα(si|tai)β(ai|i,lt,ls)(3)(3)pθIBM2(s1…sls,a1…als|t1…tlt,ls)=∏ilsα(si|tai)β(ai|i,lt,ls)

XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX

Training IBM Model 2 with the EM Algorithm

Training Model 2 is challenging:

  • we have gold sentence alignments
  • but no gold word alignments!

The Expectation Maximization (EM) Algorithm is a standard training algorithm for partially observed data. It maximizes a lower bound of the likelihood

∑(ti,si)∈trainlogpIBM2θ(si|ti)=∑(ti,si)∈trainlog∑apIBM2θ(si,a|ti)∑(ti,si)∈Dtrainlog⁡pθIBM2(si|ti)=∑(ti,si)∈Dtrainlog⁡∑apθIBM2(si,a|ti)

EM can be be seen as block coordinate descent on this bound.

EM for Model 2 iterates between:

  • E-Step: given a current set of parameters θθ, calculate the expectations ππ of the latent alignment variables under the model pIBM2θpθIBM2 — this amounts to estimating a soft alignment for each sentence.
  • M-Step: Given training set of soft alignments ππ, find new parameters θθ that maximize the log likelihood of this (weighted) training set. This amounts to soft counting.

E-Step

  • Calculate distribution over alignments

π(a|s,t)=pIBM2θ(a|s,t)π(a|s,t)=pθIBM2(a|s,t)

  • Distribution factorizes:

π(a|s,t)=∏ilsπ(ai|s,t,i)=∏ilsα(si|tai)β(ai|i,lt,ls)∑ltjα(si|tj)β(j|i,lt,ls)π(a|s,t)=∏ilsπ(ai|s,t,i)=∏ilsα(si|tai)β(ai|i,lt,ls)∑jltα(si|tj)β(j|i,lt,ls)

//Each element in the sequence corresponds to one source token,
//and each element in the nested sequence to a target token.
type Align = IndexedSeq[IndexedSeq[Double]]
//Model parameters
case class Model(
  alpha:Map[(String,String),Double],
  beta:Map[(Int,Int,Int,Int),Double]) 
//normalizing a distribution
def norm(v:IndexedSeq[Double]) = { val s = v.sum; v map (_ / s) } 
//estimate new soft alignments
def eStep(model:Model, data:Seq[(Sentence,Sentence)]):Seq[Align] = {
  for ((target,source) <- data) yield {
    def score(si:Int, ti:Int) = 
      model.alpha(source.tokens(si).word,target.tokens(ti).word) * 
      model.beta(ti,si,target.tokens.length, source.tokens.length)
    for (si <- source.tokens.indices) yield 
      norm(for (ti <- target.tokens.indices) yield score(si,ti))
  }
}

M-Step

  • Calculate weighted maximum likelihood estimate:

θ∗=argmaxθ∑(t,s)∈train∑aπ(a|t,s)logpIBM2θ(s,a|t)θ∗=argmaxθ⁡∑(t,s)∈Dtrain∑aπ(a|t,s)log⁡pθIBM2(s,a|t)

  • Closed form solution (weighted counting):

α(s|t)=∑(t,s)∑lsi∑ltjπ(j|i)δ(s,si)δ(t,tj)∑(t,s)∑ltjδ(t,tj)α(s|t)=∑(t,s)∑ils∑jltπ(j|i)δ(s,si)δ(t,tj)∑(t,s)∑jltδ(t,tj)

δ(x,y)δ(x,y) is 1 if x=yx=y and 0 otherwise

Let us implement the M-Step now. In this step we estimate parameters θθ from a given set of (soft) alignments aa.

def mStep(aligns:Seq[Align],data:Seq[(Sentence,Sentence)]) = {
  val alpha = new HashMap[(String,String),Double] withDefaultValue 0.0
  val alphaNorm = new HashMap[String,Double] withDefaultValue 0.0
  val beta = new HashMap[(Int,Int,Int,Int),Double] withDefaultValue 0.0
  val betaNorm = new HashMap[(Int,Int,Int),Double] withDefaultValue 0.0
  for ((pi,(t,s)) <- aligns zip data) {
    for (ti <- t.tokens.indices; si <- s.tokens.indices) {
      alpha(s.tokens(si).word,t.tokens(ti).word) += pi(si)(ti) 
      alphaNorm(t.tokens(ti).word) += pi(si)(ti) 
      beta(ti,si,t.tokens.length,s.tokens.length) += pi(si)(ti)
      betaNorm(si,t.tokens.length,s.tokens.length) += pi(si)(ti)
    }  
  }                 
  Model(
    alpha.toMap map {case ((s,t),p) => ((s,t), p / alphaNorm(t))} withDefaultValue 0.0,
    beta.toMap map {case ((ti,si,ls,lt),p) => ((ti,si,ls,lt),p / betaNorm(si,ls,lt))} 
withDefaultValue 0.0)    
}

Notice that the algorithm already figured out that "is" is most likely translated to "ist". This is because it is (softly) aligned with "is" in every sentence, whereas other German words only appear in a subset of the sentences.

Initialization (IBM Model 1)

Due to non-convexity of the EM bound, good initialization is crucial.

We can train IBM Model 1, which fixes the distortion parameters βββ to be uniform:

β(ai|i,lt,ls)=1lt+1β(ai|i,lt,ls)=1lt+1β(ai|i,lt,ls)=1lt+1

After training the parameters θθθ of Model 1 can be used to initialize EM for Model 2.

EM for IBM Model 1 converges to a global optimum.

Let us train IBM Model 1 now. This amounts to using our previous eStep and mStep methods, initializing βββ as above and not updating it during mStep.

def change(a1:Seq[Align],a2:Seq[Align]) = {
  val flatA1 = a1.flatMap(_.flatten) 
  val flatA2 = a2.flatMap(_.flatten)
  val diffs = (flatA1 zip flatA2) map {case(p1,p2) => math.abs(p1 - p2)}
  diffs.sum / flatA1.length
}
def emModel1(init:Model, data:Seq[(Sentence,Sentence)], iterations:Int) = {
  var model = init
  var alignments = data.map(d => d._2.tokens.map(t => d._1.tokens.map(_ => 0.0)))
  for (_ <- 0 until iterations) yield {
    val old = alignments
    alignments = eStep(model, data)
    model = mStep(alignments, data).copy(beta = init.beta) 
    (alignments,model,change(old,alignments))
  }                   
}

def emModel2(init:Model, data:Seq[(Sentence,Sentence)], iterations:Int) = {

  var alignments = data.map(d => d._2.tokens.map(t => d._1.tokens.map(_ => 0.0)))

    val old = alignments
    alignments = eStep(model, data)
    model = mStep(alignments, data)
    (alignments,model,change(old,alignments))
  }                   
}

Decoding for IBM Model 2

Decoding IBM Model 2 ideally means:

argmaxtpIBM2θ(s|t)=argmaxt∑apIBM2θ(s,a|t)(4)(4)argmaxt⁡pθIBM2(s|t)=argmaxt⁡∑apθIBM2(s,a|t)argmaxtpIBM2θ(s|t)=argmaxt∑apIBM2θ(s,a|t)(4)

This nested argmax/sum is generally computationally very hard. It's easier to argmax over target and alignments:

argmaxt,apIBM2θ(s,a|t)(5)(5)argmaxt,a⁡pθIBM2(s,a|t)argmaxt,apIBM2θ(s,a|t)(5)

A simplified same-length decoder in Scala, using a beam:

case class Hypothesis(target:List[String], align:Map[Int,Int], remaining:Set[Int],
                      score:Double, parent:Option[Hypothesis]= None)
type Beam = List[Hypothesis]
 
def decodeModel2(tm:Model, lm:LanguageModel, 
                 source:IndexedSeq[String], beamSize:Int) = {
  
  def score(hyp:Hypothesis,newTarget:String,sourceIndex:Int) = {
    val targetLength = source.length + 1
    val history = hyp.target.take(lm.order - 1).reverse
    val lmProb = math.log(lm.probability(newTarget,history:_*))
    val tmProb = math.log(tm.alpha((source(sourceIndex),newTarget))) + math.log(tm.beta
((hyp.target .length, sourceIndex, targetLength, source.length)))
    lmProb + tmProb
  }
  def append(hyp:Hypothesis) = { for (sourceIndex <- hyp.remaining; targetWord <- lm.vocab
) yield 
    Hypothesis(targetWord :: hyp.target, 
               hyp.align + (sourceIndex -> hyp.target.length), 
               hyp.remaining - sourceIndex, 
               hyp.score + score(hyp,targetWord,sourceIndex), 
               Some(hyp))} 
  
  var beam:Beam = List(Hypothesis(List("NULL"), Map.empty, source.indices.toSet,  0.0))   
 
  var history:List[Beam] = List(beam) 
  while (beam.head.remaining.nonEmpty) {
    val withNewTarget = beam.flatMap(hyp => append(hyp)).distinct
    beam = withNewTarget.sortBy(-_.score).take(beamSize).toList
    history ::= beam
  }  
  history.map(_.map(h => h.copy(target = h.target.reverse))).reverse
}

Note that "a man is tall" is also more likely in the Google N-grams corpus.

Summary

There are a few high level messages to take away from this chapter.

  • MT is an instance structured prediction recipe
  • The noisy channel is one modeling framework
  • word-based MT is foundation and blue print for more complex models
  • Training with EM
  • NLP Tricks:
    • introducing latent alignment variables to simplify problem
    • decoding with Beams
